findings.metric: Fraction of tumor proteins in immunopeptidome
findings.interpretation: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination resulted in a substantially broader representation of tumor proteins in the MHC-bound peptide pool, indicating enhanced antigen display capability

findings.metric: Fraction of proteins in MHC-I peptidome
findings.interpretation: The MHC-I presented peptide landscape nearly doubled following vaccination, demonstrating a strong expansion of the antigen presentation repertoire
The vaccinated subgroup demonstrated statistically significant improved survival outcomes compared to unvaccinated patients when receiving ICI treatment
mRNA vaccination induced a marked 3.1-fold increase in type I interferon signaling within the tumor microenvironment
PD-L1 expression in tumor tissue increased 2.4-fold following vaccination, making the checkpoint axis more therapeutically targetable
Combination therapy with vaccine and ICI resulted in increased CD8+ T-cell infiltration into tumor tissue

controls_or_null_results.statement: Vaccine-only treatment did not produce durable tumor control in non-immunogenic models, demonstrating the necessity of combining with ICI for therapeutic effect
ICI-only treatment showed limited activity in low-immunogenic baseline tumor settings, highlighting the importance of vaccine-induced priming
Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect, confirming that the mRNA component is essential for the observed phenomenon

Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit, demonstrating that interferon signaling is mechanistically required for vaccine-mediated tumor sensitization
